fields.label_text:
<font -b>SERVICE</font> 
Makers:  Jean-Baptiste Claude Odiot (1763-1850), Charles-Nicolas Odiot (1789-1868)
Paris:  about 1800-1830
Silver-gilt, ebony
M.3 to c, 4 to c, 5,6,7-1973

This composite service by two Odiots, father and son, comprises of a hot water urn (date mark for 1798-1809), sugar bowl (1809-1819), tea caddy (1819-1838), teapot and jug (both 1826-1838).  A coffee pot is probably missing.  The service was probably made up under the Restoration (1814-1830).  After the Revolution of 1789 J.-B. C. Odiot distanced himself from Paris and the Terror by serving in the army.  He then resumed the business maintained by his wife and at the 1802 Paris Exhibition shared a gold medal with Henry Auguste.

fields.descriptive_line: Sugar bowl with lid and liner, silver-gilt, Paris 1809-19, mark of Jean-Baptiste Claude Odiot

fields.name: Art and Design in Europe and America, 1800-1900

fields.physical_description: Sugar bowl with lid and liner.  Silver-gilt (two colours).  The bowl, with everted rim, bulging body and low circular base, is fitted with a liner and detachable beaded rim.  The nedge of the rim overhangs and is decorated with egg-and-dart.  The everted side of the rim is decorated with pairs of couchant monsters with swan heads, necks and wings, serpent tails and lion paws.  Between them female masks alternate with classical plant motifs.  This decoration is bolted to the surface.  The flat lit is topped by a knot in the form of a bunch of palm leaves, with a rosette in the middle.  The base, which is bolted to the bowl, is decorated with a foliated wreath and on its everted upper edge with a bunch of palm leaves.  The bowl is supported by three naked boys, each eating from a bunch of grapes held is his right hand.  They kneel on a tall cylindrical plinth, whose projecting base is decorated on its upper and lower edges with palm leaves.  To the plinth are applied (by bolting) five classical figures engaged in a sacrificial procession.  A man carries a tripod, its stem encircled aby a serpent:  a woman, two doves, a man, a jar of wine, a second woman, a basket of roses.  A third woman appears to be a priestess or devotee.
fields.dimensions: Height: 43 cm maximum, Width: 18.5 cm maximum
fields.materials_techniques: Silver gilt in two colours, ebony
fields.label:
<font -b>SERVICE</font> 
Makers:  Jean-Baptiste Claude Odiot (1763-1850), Charles-Nicolas Odiot (1789-1868)
Paris:  about 1800-1830
Silver-gilt, ebony
M.3 to c, 4 to c, 5,6,7-1973

This composite service by two Odiots, father and son, comprises of a hot water urn (date mark for 1798-1809), sugar bowl (1809-1819), tea caddy (1819-1838), teapot and jug (both 1826-1838).  A coffee pot is probably missing.  The service was probably made up under the Restoration (1814-1830).  After the Revolution of 1789 J.-B. C. Odiot distanced himself from Paris and the Terror by serving in the army.  He then resumed the business maintained by his wife and at the 1802 Paris Exhibition shared a gold medal with Henry Auguste. [1987]
fields.marks:
Maker's mark of Jean-Baptiste Claude Odiot (b.1763, master 1785, d.1850).
 Standard mark:  First standard mark for silver in use in Paris from 1 September 1809 to 15 August 1819.
 Excise mark:  Medium excise mark for silver in use between 1 Spetember 1809 and 15 August 1819.
 Restricted warranty mark:  The boar's head in use in Paris from 10 May 1838.  This is struck on the lid, knob, liner, bowl base of the bowl, one boy, and the plinth.
fields.public_access_description: This sugar bowl is part of a composite tea service consisting of a hot water urn, sugar bowl, tea caddy, teapot and ewer.  The firm of  Jean-Baptiste-Claude Odiot was one of the most important and influential Parisian silversmiths at the beginning of the 19th century. Skilful practitioners of the neo-classical style, Odiot were patronised by the aristocracy of Europe. J.B. C. Odiot's son, Charles Nicolas studied English technique and style at Garrards and took over the family business in 1827. Tea drinking after dinner became fashionable in the early 19th century, even in France. In 1827, Domestic Economy and Cookery for Rich and Poor  reported that  "In France, now, the tea-table is partially introduced to accommodate the English, which serves to show off their nice cakes and bon bons…"
fields.exhibition_history: Art and Design in Europe and America, 1800-1900 (Victoria and Albert Museum 01/01/1987-31/12/2000)
fields.bibliography: Ronald Lightbown: <u>French Silver</u> Victoria and Albert Museum Catalogues, London, HMSO. 1978, pp. 110-11 ill. ISBN. 0112902502
fields.credit: Purchased with the assistance of The Art Fund
fields.history_note:
Bought from Messers. Frank Partridge, New Bond Street, London.
From a tea service. Part of a composite tea-service with elements by J.C.-B and his son Charles-Nicolas Odiot. Probably made up during the Restoration.  This is part of a composite tea service, made up from pieces marked for Jean-Baptiste (master 1785) and his son Charles-Nicolas Odiot (mark in use from 1826).

Historical significance: The Odiot workshop was one of the largest, most prestigious in Paris, supplying the court and aristocracy. It was quite usual to make up sets of tea, coffee or other services from stock. Designs and casting patterns were kept and re-used as necessary.

The bowl is characteristic of Odiot's production and the so-called "Empire" style, popular in France in the early 19th century. The use of classical motifs and figures applied to plain surfaces, and for pouring vessels, spouts ending in animal's heads are typical. It was considered the epitome of French stylishness in England. The French craft, on the other hand, looked to England for technical developments; Charles-Nicolas spent some time working as a modeller for Garrards in London.
